results.title: The Rules of the game = La Regle du jeu
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Claude Renoir and Nouvelle Edition Francaise
results.brief_description: On its initial release Renoir’s masterwork was greeted with contempt by critics, hostility by audiences and banned by the French government as “subversive” and “demoralising”. This restored version, put together under Renoir’s direction, makes available again one of the most acclaimed films ever made. A group of wealthy aristocratic and bourgeois Parisians holiday at their friend’s country chateau. There, as their amoral relationships turn alternately tragic or absurd, their lives and class are revealed as ultimately empty and decaying. Featuring some of the most beautifully constructed and edited sequences in film, Renoir’s direction - though seemingly understated - manages to convey the richness and complexity of a whole era and class: an era that World War II was to bring to an end. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: December bride
results.creator_credit: Thaddeus O'Sullivan, Jonathan Cavendish, British Screen, Central TV, Film Four International and Little Bird
results.brief_description: Unfolding against the rolling contours of the beautiful Ulster coastline Thaddeus O’Sullivan’s film is a brooding and stunningly photographed drama of broken taboos within the harshly repressive atmosphere of a turn-of-the-century Presbyterian community. Sarah is the servant girl left alone on the Echlin farm with brothers Hamilton and Frank. Her subsequent pregnancy outrages local minister Sorleyson when she refuses to name the father or marry either of the two men. But can she find a way of living with the consequences that neither ostracises the family completely nor runs against her steadfastly independent principles.

results.title: An Unfinished piece for mechanical piano
results.brief_description: Platonov is thirty-five and believes he is a failure. Caught between ex-lovers at a wealthy widow’s estate, he recalls youthful ideas while facing present reality. This sparkling adaptation is based on Chekhov’s first play ‘Platonov’, and it reveals the essence of the writer’s tragi-comic world. An outstanding cast of leading Russian actors makes it the most idiomatic of all Chekhov films. Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Solaris [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Andrei Tarkovsky, Magna Corporation and Mosfilm
results.brief_description: A psychologist is sent to a spaceship orbiting the planet Solaris to investigate the mysterious disappearances and deaths that have occurred on the ship. He discovers that madness has overtaken the occupants of the craft, who are haunted by the material presence of their guilty past. Soon, the psychologist too finds his past coming back to him in the shape of his dead wife. “Solaris” is an extraordinary science fiction movie that utilises the genre to investigate the increasing alienation and isolation of humanity, a condition accelerated by the rapid advances of technology. The film is ravishing to look at, from its opening shots of a meadow on earth, to the long gliding takes across the surface of the metallic craft. With “Solaris” Tarkovsky established a reputation as the finest Russian film-maker since the days of the silent masters. Along with Kubrick’s “2001”, Tarkovsky’s film is an intelligent and intensely communicated masterwork of science-fiction cinema. From the novel by Stanislaw Lem. Winner of the Special Jury Prize, 1972 Cannes Film Festival.

results.title: Stalker
results.brief_description: In a bleak post-industrial future, in an unnamed country, mysterious Zones have appeared which offer the fulfilment of all desire: to navigate the Zone, however, one risks life and sanity. A Professor and a Writer hire a Stalker to guide them through the Zone. The two intellectuals are seeking answers to their anguished search for meaning; the Stalker is seeking a cure for his daughter’s deformities for which he blames himself. By stripping the science- fiction genre of all its trappings of hardware and effects, Tarkovsky has created an ascetic masterwork of hypnotic imagery and meditative mise-en-scene. In “Stalker” we confront the mystery and agony of humankind’s spiritual isolation. Trapped within a decaying, materialistic world only the Stalker’s hoped for redemption through faith can counter the Professor’s and the Writer’s metaphysical pessimism. Made at a time when the director was engaged in a hostile battle of wills with the Soviet state, “Stalker” is an allegory of spiritual struggle, and it is a richly transcendental work of cinema. Based on the book “Roadside Picnic” by Arcady and Boris Strugatsky. NOTE: The prologue is in black and white.

results.title: Un Chant d'amour. Flames of passion. Looking for Langston (X)
results.creator_credit: Isaac Julien, Jean Genet, Richard Kwietniowski, Cheryl Farthing, Nadine Marsh-Edwards, Niko Papatakis and BFI
results.brief_description: Three important and poetic films exploring homoeroticism. (1)”Un Chant d’Amour” is the only film directed by Jean Genet. A silent movie filmed in 1950, the film sensuously explores the themes that obsessed Genet in his writing: homosexual love and desire within the oppressive confines of prison. This explicit film was banned from circulation for 20 years. (2)”Flames of Passion”, made in 1989, is a witty gay remake of “Brief Encounter”. (3)”Looking for Langston” (1989) is dedicated to the black artists of the Harlem Renaissance. Writers such as Langston Hughes and James Baldwin not only celebrated the African-American history suppressed by white society but also liberated black homosexual desire. “Looking for Langston” is a beautiful and erotic essay on black men’s love for each other and the difficulty of negotiating gay love in a racist culture. From the director of “Young Soul Rebels”.
results.title_for_label: Un Chant d’amour. Flames of passion. Looking for Langston (X)

results.title: Housekeeping
results.creator_credit: Bill Forsyth, Robert F. Colesberry and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Abandoned early in life, Ruth and Lucille have been raised by various relatives - now it’s Aunt Sylvie’s (Christine Lahti) turn. But Aunt Sylvie isn’t like their other relatives, she used to be a hobo and can’t seem to change her eccentric ways. She takes midday naps on park benches and wears an overcoat lined with old newspapers. Sylvie may be embarrassing, but she’s like a breath of fresh air to the two girls. Can Lucille and Ruth cope with Sylvie, and can Sylvie cope with the real responsibility of a family? This is a beautiful story of quirky relationships, loneliness, and the bonding of kindred spirits. Based on the book by Marilynne Robinson.

results.title: I know where I'm going
results.creator_credit: Emeric Pressburger, Michael Powell and Archers Film Productions
results.brief_description: Joan (Wendy Hiller) has known exactly what she wanted since childhood, and all her dreams are to come true with her forthcoming marriage to a millionaire - but a storm strands her on a remote Hebridean island and the forces of nature conspire to change her mind. With its overwhelming sense of place and stunning visual effects, this most personal of Powell and Pressburger’s films is also one of their most perfect. “I had reached the point of thinking there were no more masterpieces, until I saw ‘I Know Where I’m Going’.” Martin Scorsese
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emeric Pressburger, Michael Powell and Archers Film Productions

results.title: Camille Claudel
results.brief_description: Artistic genius and the descent into madness are at the centre of this stunning drama about Camille Claudel. An independent woman, she ventured into the male dominated sphere of sculpture in the 1880’s and left an indelible mark on the genre. After achieving an apprenticeship to renowned sculptor, Auguste Rodin (24 years older than she), and reaching a level of intimacy with him, she longs for more. His refusal initiates a decline in their relationship and her sanity. Based upon the biography of Camille Claudel by Rein-Marie Paris, great niece of Camille, this hauntingly dark and brooding film will sweep its audience along the raging torrent that was Camille Claudel’s life. Stars Gerard Depardieu and Isabelle Adjani. English subtitles with French dialogue.

results.title: What have I done to deserve this? = Que he hecho yo para merecer esto?
results.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, Tadeo Villabla, Kaktus S A and Tesauro S A
results.brief_description: Gloria is a housewife with attitude. She has to be: one son is a drug dealer, her youngest son is having an affair with the family dentist, her husband can’t excite her anymore, and her mother-in-law is determined to drive her crazy. To survive in the concrete jungle of Madrid, Gloria snorts cleaning powders and searches for sex with masculine strangers. This wickedly funny movie is an early feature by Almodovar and it revels in inverting and satirising the conventions of television soap opera and of the Hollywood “women’s film”. Absurd, fast-paced and stylistically innovative, “What Have I Done to Deserve This?” stars the fabulous Carmen Maura.
